required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Conservative and Operative Treatment of Jones Fracture
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Conservative and Operative Treatment of Jones Fracture

brief_summary.textblock: The study deals with the topic of treatment of Jones fracture, comparing surgical and conservative approach. The fracture occurs especially in highly active individuals.

detailed_description.textblock:
The study deals with the topic of treatment of Jones fracture, comparing surgical and conservative approach. The fracture occurs especially in highly active individuals.
The study proposes a supposition of recommending the active operational approach, which shortens the period of healing by 6 weeks, limitation of physical activity by 4 weeks, and sick leave by 2 months. It also completely eliminates the need to perform a rigid fixation of the extremity for 8-12 weeks.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The patients with Jones fracture were randomized into one of the two study groups - operational or conservative approach.
study_design_info.masking_description: No masking was used in the study

primary_outcome.measure: The American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS) score - 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The improvement in The American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS) score from the baseline was observed at 6 weeks after injury on a scale of 0-100.
The improvement in The American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS) score from the baseline was observed at 12 months after injury on a scale of 0-100.

secondary_outcome.measure: Signs of healing on X-ray at 6 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The presence or absence of signs of healing on X-ray were observed at 6 weeks after injury.

secondary_outcome.measure: Signs of healing on X-ray at 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: The presence or absence of signs of healing on X-ray were observed at 12 months after injury.
The ability to load the injured extremity was measured in per cent of full loading.

arm_group.description: The patients enrolled in this arm underwent surgical treatment of the Jones fracture.
The patients enrolled in this arm were treated conservatively, using fixation of the injured extremity.

intervention.description: Operational approach was used to treat the Jones fracture in patients randomized into the respective study arm.
Conservative approach was used to treat the Jones fracture in patients randomized into the respective study arm.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Jones fracture
Exclusion Criteria:
- combined injury
- recurring injury
- diabetes mellitus
- chronic renal insufficiency
- osteopathy

Mindrebo N, Shelbourne KD, Van Meter CD, Rettig AC. Outpatient percutaneous screw fixation of the acute Jones fracture. Am J Sports Med. 1993 Sep-Oct;21(5):720-3.

STEWART IM. Jones's fracture: fracture of base of fifth metatarsal. Clin Orthop. 1960;16:190-8.

clinical_study.keyword: The American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS)

patient_data.ipd_description: The researchers do not plan to share individual participant data with other researchers.
